Thus principle is how internal combustion engines ignited fuel in cylinders before electronic ignition became a thing. A car"s ignition system had contact points, a condenser (capacitor) and a coil (inductor). When the ignition was on current was supplied to the capacitor and coil, both of which stored electrical energy. The starter motor turned the crankshaft to force the pistons and valves  to cycle through their phases, drawing in fuel-air mixture and compressing it. The contact points conducted current until. a lobe caused them to open a small gap that interrupted the current flow. The magnetic field in the coil collapsed causing a spark across the small air-gap in the selected spark plug igniting the fuel-air mixture in the cylinder and causing a power stroke to turn the crankshaft.

Near here, in Folsem CA there is the FOLSEM POWERHOUSE - a small museum around the generators and equipment that generated electricity for street lighting once upon a time. They have a knife switch (same idea as the switch Physics Girl used) but it has a part that stays in the terminal until the handle pulls far enough away, at that point a spring 'snaps' the part out of the terminal very quickly, breaking the circuit quickly to minimize spark. That spark can actually eventually damage the switch so in high power situations they want to minimize it. This switch controlled the 300-volt output of one of the generators (they had 2 and 2 sets of these switches.) https://www.parks.ca.gov/pages/501/files/FolsomPowerhouse.pdf shows a picture of the switchboard.

Sorry, but your summary is a little off.  An inductor produces higher voltage than what was put into it, when the circuit is opened due to the energy stored in its magnetic field collapsing.  The current produced by this effect flows in the opposite direction to the flow of current when the circuit is closed (when powered by DC).  It’s a misnomer to think of it as the momentum of current, or relate it to water hammer.  Also, circuits generally have flyback diodes to allow prevent the excess voltage from damaging components, so you shouldn’t get a spark when unplugging a well designed inductive circuit.

Inductors tend to resist changes in current.  The reason is because as the current changes so does the magnetic field.  A changing magnetic field induces a voltage (E) and current (I) in the wire in the opposite direction.  If you were to watch the current flow into those large electromagnets you would see a HUGE spike when the switch is closed but then the current would level out as the magnetic field levels out.  When you open the switch that magnetic field that stored all of that energy collapses through the coils.  This moving magnetic field induces another current in the wire which is shown in the huge amount of energy at the switch.  You can take a large coil of wire and attach it to a small battery and hold the ends of the wire.  When you close the circuit you feel nothing but when you open it with one end of the wire in each hand you get quite a jolt because of the back EMF caused by the collapsing magnetic field.

Here is the details missing from the explanation:
There is a ferromagnetic piece of metal in the center of the coil of wire. The act like a reservoir of magnetic energy. When we apply current, there magnetic field grow progressively by rotating each magnetic domain, which are random initially. As more and more domain rotate, the electric energy gets stored as magnetic field. Eventually, all magnetic domain are aligned, we have reached saturation. At that point, the electric energy in the coil become a wasted as heat.
When removing the electric source, the inductor attempt to maintain the same current. It will raise the voltage as much as possible until it succeed to force the same current as before. As the electric energy flow out of the inductor (being spent as heat and light in the electric arc on the switch), each magnetic domain return to their original position.

When all magnetic domain finally return to their rest angle, the inductor stop providing electric current, so the arc in the contact of the switch stop.

In the case of high voltage transformer, like still used in any car to create the arc on the spark plug, the natural attempt to reach the voltage is used to get about 120 volt from the 12 volt of the battery. This is the voltage that we can measure on the primary side, where the contact (or transistor) send pulse synchronized with the rotation of the cam shaft. The secondary is made of about 20 times more turns then the primary, thus raising the 120 volt to the 2400 volt needed for the spark plug.

In case of CRT TV which needed 25 kilovolt to accelerate the electron on the screen, the same "flywheel" effect is used to increase the voltage from 120 volt pulsed DC to 1200 volt short spike on the primary and then 10 kilovolt on the secondary. A voltage tripler is then used to reach 25 kv, about 5 kv being lost from the high impedance of the coupling capacitors. The first "all solid state" TV appeared in 1976 when a high voltage transistor (1500 volt) was finally successfully built.

For switching power supplies, the kick back (flywheel) effect of the inductor is rarely needed. Instead, it is the constant current which is exploited by using low impedance output to force the voltage to remain under tight control. Fast PWM pulses are used with the width of the pulse constantly adjusted using negative feedback loop to maintain a fixed voltage while responding to variable current from variable load. A typical laptop quickly alternate between 1 amp and 3 amps, sometime changing the load current many times every second. The PWM pulse width is effectively modulating the total energy entering the switching inductor in order to adjust the current as required by sudden start or sdtop of CD rom motor, video card rush current triggered by different scene in a video game, etc

An easier way to understand: let's say the switch goes from fully engaged to completely disengaged in a short but finite amount of time. Let's evaluate the boundary conditions: when the switch is fully engaged, there is current through the circuit, supporting the magnetic field. When the switch is fully disengaged, there is no current through the circuit, and therefore no magnetic field. Now that means all the energy has to be dissipated in the finite amount of time.

The resistance of the circuit, in other terms, basically describes how much power you burn given a voltage across it. Since the energy has to dissipate rather quickly at a rate that exceeds the original rate of dissipation (= voltage of the power source), it logically means that the voltage has to rise to meet the power dissipation speed.

An electronics book I read compared it to how a generator works. Generators make energy when a moving magnets lines of flux pass through an inductor generating an emf(voltage). When inductors are first turned on it initially has no field but then as current flows, it develops a field which has to grow. The growing field is the same thing as a moving magnet in a generator from the inductors perspective so it develops an emf which leads to a current in the opposite direction to the current from the power supply slowing it down like resistance(inductive reactance). Eventually, the growth of the magnetic field cutting through the inductor slows decreasing the generated opposing voltage leading to a decrease in opposing currents letting current flow from the power supply with minimal resistance. Now if you stop current from flowing, the fields magnetic lines of flux begin to collapse and again are like an external magnets lines of flux moving through the inductor making it generate current. Although current is now flowing in the same direction as the initial flow from a power supply. These effects from the lines of flux growing or collapsing and then cutting through coils is how current behaves like it has momentum which has to be built up and then released.

To think about induction, I think it's helpful to think about Lenz Law.

1. A changing magnetic field induces a voltage.
2. If the rate is not steady, then the voltage will also change.
3. A voltage will be accompanied by an electric field, so a changing voltage will be accompanied by a changing electric field.
4. A changing electric field creates a magnetic field.

So there's two options:
A. either this changing electric field will create a magnetic field that supports the original change in the magnetic field or
B. the changing electric field will create a magnetic field that opposes the original change

Case A is basically a self propulsion machine because if you increased the magnetic field a bit, then the induced voltage would induce a magnetic field that would support the original change, and you'd get this back and forth feedback effect that would continue forever with growing amplitudes/energy

So it has to be Case B. When the magnetic field changes, it induces a voltage that will create an electric field that will create a magnetic field that will OPPOSE the original change.

Dropping a magnet through a copper pipe is related to it for me. The magnetic field increases then decreases as the magnet passes through. The magnetic fields that are induced are opposite the direction of the falling magnet to reduce the original change (otherwise the magnet would speed up as it passed through the tube and you'd get that self-propagating effect)

Almost every typical gasoline spark-ignition engine in cars still uses traditional "IDI" (Inductive Discharge Ignition) high-inductance Coils with the HV generated by transforming up the voltage spike of the back-EMF pulse. So you basicly "turn off" the coil to make the spark. The saturation level of the laminated Iron core is what sets the energy amount of the spark. The difference beeing more modern materials, and using IGBT's instead of breakerpoints and capacitors. Some cars tho (a bit rare) and smaller or very high rpm engines (quite often) uses "CDI" (Capacitor Discharge Ignition) Where IGBT's or Thyristors are used to dump 400V (or so) directly into the primary winding of a special low-inductance coil ("pulse-transformer") without using back-EMF (there hardly is any back-EMF either due to the low inductance).

Like the capacitor counteracts to the voltage change with current the inductor counteracts to the current change with voltage. At the university they told us that if you try to break the current through an inductor the current will continue to flow until all the energy is dissipated. It will find where to jump - the turned off semiconductor, between the switch contacts or if not there between the coil windings. The voltage which can be produced by the coil in order to maintain the current is infinite. In real conditions it's limited at first place by the parasitic capacitance between the windings which capacitance is charging and the peak of voltage is lowered to some finite value. And if that limitation is not enough it can jump between the windings ruining the coil. So that's about it, remember it's impossible to change the current through a coil abruptly. As it's impossible to change the voltage of a capacitor abruptly. Of course in the real world there are limitations but keeping that in mind helps a lot when designing or trying to understand an electronic circuit.

Inductors cause the current to lead the voltage. Why? Because they don't actually impede the flow of charge (that is, electrons), but the magnetic field induced by the flow of charge through that coil does impede the electromotive potential (that is, the voltage) from getting through the wire.

Capacitors have the reverse effect: Voltage flows across them quite easily, but the current? Not so much. In this case, the voltage difference will create a current in the other wire, but it will lag the voltage.

I like your channel, and this video too. But while I like your expose about induction, I think your into about the spark (actually, it is an arc, not a spark, when you break a circuit) in the switch is a bit of a red herring. The induction story doesn't describe why you always get an arc. Of course you can argue that no circuit really has L=0 mH. But even without that argument you get an arc: when you break the circuit there is a potential difference over the gap. At first that gap is extremely small so that a discharge can happen very easily. That creates a conductive channel (plasma) that will be visible as an arc. And because it is already conducting, it will keep going. So you don't need the masses of energy, or momentum, to be able to "jump the gap". How violent the arc is will of course depend on how much energy is stored in the circuit, either in inductors or elsewhere.

You forgot to answer the question of why a plug sparks when you plug in a modern power supply. That has to do with connecting large capacitance (with a low resistance) to a high voltage power source (120VAC) I=V/R. The brief connect/disconnect before the plug is fully mated dumps a ton of current into the load of the filter capacitors (several hundred microfarads usually) causing a spark. In fact, this problem can become so large (think Farads of capacitance) that you need what are called pre-charge resistors to slowly charge up the capacitors before disconnecting so as not to waste power. These are mostly needed in electric vehicles were you have heavy filter capacitors in the inverter and 400VDC from the battery, you would blow out your contactors if you didn't manage it. Here's one intuitive/visual interpretation of magnetic field collapse and EMF:

When the switch is opened, there is no longer any energy input to sustain the magnetic field. So the magnetic field collapses. As it collapses, the field lines pass through the conductors.

We know that relative motion between a conductor and a magnetic field will cause a current to be induced in the conductor. This is the law of induction.

So the collapsing magnetic field will induce a current.

Because the circuit is open, the energy of collapse doesn't cause a large number of charge carriers to flow at a low voltage, but instead causes a smaller number of charge carriers to flow at a higher voltage, creating an arc through the air.

This is conservation of energy.

Question for the Curious: Does the current induced by the magnetic field collapse flow in the SAME or OPPOSITE direction as the current that created the magnetic field? Can you explain your reasoning both visually and mathematically?
